item.Q: What attribute must a img element have? What does it do?
item.A: src. It is a URL to a image.

item.Q:
What is the value of the selector:
#maincontent .column2 .discovery .portlet ul li a

What type of thing is class in the following element?
div class="portlet noback">...</div

What is a in this example?
x y="z">aaa</x
Do inline elements use the box model?
item.A: No, it only applies to block-level elements.

item.Q: The border is within which box model part?
What type of selector starts with a . ?

What is the value of the following selector?
body div.main #banner .bgheader

What is the first part of a css rule (x) called?
#x { y : z; }
Why is using a id selector less useful than a class?
item.A: Because an id can only be used once.

item.Q: Why are element selectors less useful than class selectors?
item.A: Element selectors change all instances of the element. They're usually too general... you spend a lot of time writing more specific rules to work around them.

item.Q: Why are inline styles a bad idea?
item.A: Because they are way too specific, they only work on the element they are apart of, and thus they can't be reused.

item.Q: Which will take precidence, a CSS rule applied to a class, or an inline rule?
item.A: An inline rule. It has a higher weight than any rule.

item.Q: What is the value of an id selector?
What is the value of a class selector?
What is the value of an element selector?
What is the value of a rule that contains !important ?
Are embedded (in-document styles) more or less useful than externally-linked styles?
item.A: Less. In-document styles can only be applied to that document, they can't be re-used across many documents.

item.Q: What element do you use to include an external stylesheet?
item.A:
link
Specifically
link rel='stylesheet' type='text/css' href='mystyle.css'

item.Q: In the case of a selector weight tie, which rule is applied?
What does the "media" attribute do on the link element?
item.A: It tells the browser what media the CSS should be applied to. For instance media="print" tells the browser that CSS should only be included when printing the page.

item.Q:
In CSS what does the following line do?
/* p { color: green; } */
What selector starts with a #
What selector starts without a # or a . ?
What is the box model?
item.A: A concept that browsers use to describe block level element styles.

item.Q: What is the outermost element of the box model?
What is the innermost element of the box model?
What piece is inside of the border in the box model?
From inside to out, what are the parts of the box model?
item.A: The content, the padding, the border, the margin.

item.Q: Is the body a block-level element? Does it have padding?
What is the outermost html element?
What is the root node of a html document?
What two children does html contain?
What is a self-closing html element?
item.A: An element that has no closing tag. or br

item.Q:
What is x in this example?
x y="z">aaa</x

What is y in this example?
x y="z">aaa</x

What is aaa in this example?
x y="z">aaa</x
Can xHTML have upper-case elements or attributes?
What is p?
What is em?
What is a dl?
What is dd?
item.A: a Definition Description, part of a Definition List.

item.Q: What is a dt?
item.A: A Definition Term, part of a Definition list.

item.Q: What is ul?
What is ol?
What child elements must a ul have ?
What is a li?
item.A: A list item, a child of an unordered or ordered list

item.Q: What is div?
item.A: Just a div, it has no meaning.

item.Q: What is span?
item.A: Just a span, it has no meaning, but is an inline element.

item.Q: Is a div an inline or block element?
Is p an inline or block element?
Is ul an inline or block element?
Is strong an inline or block element?
How many attributes can an element have?

What type of thing is inlinelist in the following element?
ul class="inlinelist"> ... </ul
What is an a element?
What attribute must an a element have? What does it do?
item.A: href, contains an attribute value of a URL (a link)

item.Q: What is an img?
How many ids can you have in an html document?
item.A: As many as you want, but none of them can have the same values

item.Q: Can you put an id attribute on body? on html?
item.A:
Yes, and yes. It doesn't really make much sense to put one on html.
It is occasionally useful to put a class or id on body however, because you can write selectors against different body conditions.

item.Q: How is div .classname different from div.classname? What does the space in-between separate?
item.A:
div . classname looks for a div with a .classname ancestor. div.classname looks for a div with the class "classname."
The space separates different parts of the selector.
